comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: That's the back of St Doulaghs on the Malahide road between Balgriffin and Kinsealy, isn't it?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here's the front: www.fingaldublin.ie/interior-pages/activities-attractions...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Excellent! And a time record - 2 minutes, was it? Looks like it to me. Thank you. Found this photo too.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: OSI Ref: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,721104,742082,7,9

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: In my youth, I used to show tourists round it. I know nothing about the place, so I just made stuff up and accepted any theories advanced by the tourists themselves, no matter how preposterous.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The woman is in the garden of Lime Hill, so she's unlikely to be associated with the church, as it's part of the United Parishes of Malahide, St Doulagh's and Portmarnock (this isn't made up) and the rectory is beside St Andrew's in Malahide.

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: A wonderful building!!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: You can probably date it from the ladder. It was refurbished sometime in the 19th century.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: That is an amazing building!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: According to wikipedia: "A modern church was added in 1864, and consecrated in 1865." Unfortunately, it's on the far side of the building, but given the general state of decay, I don't think it's happened by the time this picture was taken.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Anyway, you can get a tour of it this sunday (or you can just go to church there) malahide.dublin.anglican.org/doulaghs/index.shtml.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I have rather spoiled the fun, haven't I? Next time I'll just sit bouncing on the sidelines saying "I know this one, I know this one!"

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Fantastic building.  A bit of a shame that it was restored.

I wonder what the lady is reading?  Something by a Brontë sister perhaps?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: 1860-1864, then. Brilliant work, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] ! This original building is from the 12th century Oh and Streetview.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
What a darned interesting picture NLI, with a whole lot of charm.
That lady, in that dress, must have left a swathe through the grass!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02]  Masterclass, well done. Will you be conducting the tour on Sunday?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] Can you imagine if the grass was wet?  In the materials dresses were made of in those days it would weigh a ton by the time she got back home![http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Well done on the time.  This is just down the road from me but i was tied up all morning and just got to see it now, so you beat me to it! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Your second photo shows the new church (act of vandalism) added on to the original which corresponds with the Lemur's comment on the building.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: I've been passing that church for so many years now, so it's great to see an old photo of it, needless to say I didn't recognise it initially!

comment.author: 37107521@N00
comment._content: bizarre building - its as if a fortified tower house crashed into a church :-)

comment.author: 67513657@N05
comment._content: !Qué edificio más raro,al mismo tiempo original¡.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] No you have not spoiled the fun but I am sitting here in open mouthed amazement..Lol!!

comment.author: 44191635@N04
comment._content: best shot

comment.author: 78381216@N00
comment._content: . . . and as it was in 2009!

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Queen Victoria on a walkabout?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I just discovered there's a picture of St Doulagh's with an orgy taking place at the holy well in front of it in the National Gallery. The gallery staff haven't recognised the place either and it's listed as an imaginative composition. Have none of this shower ever corssed the Liffey?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Have you a link for that picture?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: No. I looked on their website but it's not online. I saw it a fortnight ago, though. It definitely exists.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I tell a lie. It is online if you know where to look: onlinecollection.nationalgallery.ie/media/view/Objects/16...

comment._content:
This was when female attire was at its most strenuous.
Must've been like going for a walk with a pup tent strapped on.
